repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: This beautiful lithograph collection of drawings contains 21 illustrations ranging from numerous scenes from the Mahābhārata storyline to some images of Hindu deities. Captions in Marathi help to identify the represented characters and sometimes the details of the action. The book was obtained in Bombay by Charles d'Ochoa in the mid-19th century during a mission in search of manuscripts and printed sources.
The title, Illustrations of Hindoo Mythology, is taken from the catalogue entry of Cabaton, which in turn comes from an entry in the registry of acquisitions of the library.

msItem.incipit: kuṃtī yama vāyu iṃdra aśvinau kumāra

support.p: The last three illustrations are on folded folios of larger size (485 x305 mm). Folios 16 through 18 are in blue paper.

extent.measure: 1 guard, 21 numbered folios and 2 blank folios.

supportDesc.condition: Very good (only folio 19 has a small tear).

decoNote.desc: Folio 1: Kuntī and the 5 gods — Yama, Vāyu, Indra and the Āśvins —, fathers of her children.

Folio 2: The churning of the ocean of milk. Śrīhari sits on top of Mount Mandara, mounted on its turn on the back of Kūrma, while the gods on one side (Mahādeva, Viṣṇu and Brahmadeva) and the demons on the other (Bāḻi, Rāhu and Ketu) are pulling on the serpent Vāsukī.
Folio 3: Duṣyanta, attended by two servants (rājabhṛtya) meets Śakuntalā and their son Bharata in front of the assembly.
Folio 4: Dharma and Nārada meet at the centre of a well-manned assembly (sabhā).
Folio 5: Vasiṣṭha offers the Rāmāyaṇa to Rāma and Sītā, surrounded by Hanumān (Māruti) and his monkey army as well as Lakṣmaṇa, Bharata and Śatrughna.
Folio 6: Arjuna and Śrīkṛṣṇa watch the gruesome scene of Bhīma splitting open the evil king Jarāsandha.
Folio 7: Draupadī is represented three times, performing various actions in front of Kṛṣṇa and in the middle of a feast offered to Brahmins.
Folio 8: Arjuna and Kṛṣṇa in their battle chariot, which carries on its banner Hanūmān (Māruti), rush towards the Khāṇḍava Forest already in flames.
Folio 9: The forest exile of the Pāṇḍava (pāṃḍavavanavāsagamana): Dharma, Bhīma, Arjuna, Nakula, Sahadeva, Draupadī and Dhaumya.
Folio 10: Duḥśāsana disrobes Draupadī in front of the assembly of Kauravas, on one side, and the five Pāṇḍava brothers and Śrīkṛṣṇa, on the other.
Folio 11: Śrīśuka performs a recitation, in a Mandira erected on the Lokastambha, in front of Parīkṣit (parikṣitī), and surrounded by Brāhamaṇas on one side, and servants (bhṛtyagaṇa) on the other.
Folio 12: In the higher register, Draupadī and the five Pāṇḍava brothers give homage to Śrīkṛṣṇa. In the lower register, Draupadī offers food to a group of sages (ṛṣipaṅktī).
Folio 13: Gaṅgā presents her son Bhīṣma to Śantanu, his father.
Folio 14: Yayāti helps Devayāni out of the well.
Folio 15: The game of dice between the Pāṇḍavas and Kauravas, the former represented on one side (Dharmarāja, Bhīma and Nakula), the latter on the other (Śakunī, Karṇa, Duryodhana and Duḥśāsana).

Folio 16: The young Pāṇḍavas and Kauravas are wrestling, training and playing (?). Duryodhana and Bhīma in the center, Arjuna, Dharma, Nakula and Sahadeva on one side, and Duḥśāsana, Śakunī, Karṇa and Śailya on the other.
Folio 17: Arjuna brings Drupada in ropes to king Droṇa.
Folio 18: Bhīṣma, accompanied by Arjuna and Dharma, offers worship to Droṇācārya (bhīṣma droṇācāryā cī pūjā karitāta).
Folio 19: Śiva and Umā on Nandin on one side and Skanda embracing her spouse on the other
Folio 20: The ṛṣi Atri (Ātrīrusī) and his father Dattātreya (Dattātrī).
Folio 21: Kṛṣṇa (or Śiva) surrounded by female attendants and musicians.

On the initial flyleaf, verso:

1847 is the year in which d'Ochoa's manuscripts were acquired by the BnF.

origin.origDate: The terminus ad quem, 1844, is the date of d'Ochoa's return to Paris (see BnF Data). Dated to the 19th century by Cabaton (1912).

provenance.p: From the collection of Charles d'Ochoa (1816-1846).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the the Minister of Public Instruction on 12 January, 1847 (number 4483 in the registry of acquisitions).
